text: The women's football tournament at the 2012 Summer Olympics was held in London and 5 other cities in the United Kingdom. This was the first FIFA women's competition in the United Kingdom. == Qualification == Twelve teams qualified: * Great Britain (Host nation) * Japan * North Korea * South Africa * Cameroon * United States * Canada * Brazil * Colombia * New Zealand * Sweden * France == Group stage == === Group E === Team Pld W D L GF GA GD Pts Great Britain 3 3 0 0 5 0 +5 9 Brazil 3 2 0 1 6 1 +5 6 New Zealand 3 1 0 2 3 3 0 3 Cameroon 3 0 0 3 1 11 –10 0 === Group F === Team Pld W D L GF GA GD Pts Sweden 3 1 2 0 6 3 +3 5 Japan 3 1 2 0 2 1 +1 5 Canada 3 1 1 1 6 4 +2 4 South Africa 3 0 1 2 1 7 –6 1 In Group F play before the official opening ceremonies, the Japanese team won the first match against Canada at Coventry on July 25 London2012, "Japan start with a win" ; retrieved 2012-7-25. The Japan-South Africa game was a draw with no goals for each team.Japan-South Africa, July 31 at London2012.com ; retrieved 2012-8-6. The Japan-Sweden game was also a draw with no score.ABCNews.com, "Sweden Holds Japan to 0-0 Tie at Olympics," July 31, 2012; retrieved 2012-8-6. === Group G === Team Pld W D L GF GA GD Pts United States 3 3 0 0 8 2 +6 9 France 3 2 0 1 8 4 +4 6 North Korea 3 1 0 2 2 6 –4 3 Colombia 3 0 0 3 0 6 –6 0 In Group G play, the American women won each of three matches. USSoccer.com, 2012 Olympic Games ; retrieved 2012-8-7. === Ranking of third place teams === Team Pld W D L GF GA GD Pts Canada 3 1 1 1 6 4 +2 4 New Zealand 3 1 0 2 3 3 0 3 North Korea 3 1 0 2 2 6 –4 3 == Knockout stage == The tournament had a single-elimination format. When a team lost a match, the competition was ended for them. In other words, when a team won, the women continued to play until only one team remained as the Olympic champion. {{quote box|style=margin-left: 4em|quote=: {{Round8 |3 August – Coventry| Great Britain|0| Canada|2 |3 August – Newcastle| New Zealand|0| United States|2 |3 August – Glasgow| Sweden|1| France|2 |3 August – Cardiff| Brazil|0| Japan|2 |6 August – Manchester| Canada|3| United States|4 |6 August – London| France|1| Japan|2 |9 August – London| United States|2| Japan|1 }} }} In the first match at St James Park in Newcastle between New Zealand and the United States, the 2-0 victory of the US women ended New Zealand's participation in the 2012 games.Woodcock, Fred. "Football Ferns eliminated by USA in quarters," Stuff.co.nz, 4 August 2012; retrieved 2012-8-7. In the semi- final match at Old Trafford in Manchester, the US women won a 4-3 victory over Canada in the last minute of extra time in overtime.Borden, Sam. "U.S. Women Win a Thriller on a Header," New York Times (US). August 7, 2012; excerpt, "Suddenly, a pink headband rose high in the air and Alex Morgan, the speedy American star forward, used her head to send the ball on a perfect arc, just over the goalkeeper’s hand and just under the crossbar, for a 4-3 victory"; see also, Jerry Hinman. "U.S. 4, Canada 3: A match great beyond great," CBSSports, August 6, 2012; retrieved 2012-8-7. In the opening match at Cardiff between Brazil and Japan, the Brazilians were forced out of the tournament after losing to Japan 2-0."Brazil make shock exit from women's football event after losing to Japan 2-0," The Telegraph (UK). August 3, 2012; retrieved 2012-8-3. In the match at Wembley Stadium in London between France and Japan, the Japanese team won 2-1."Japan reaches women’s football final after holding on to beat France 2-1," Washington Post (US), August 6, 2012; retrieved 2012-8-6. === Bronze medal match === === Gold medal match === The United States women's national soccer team and the Japan women's national football team met in the gold medal match.US Woman's National Team, "USA-JPN: Lineups Are In," August 18, 2012; excerpt, USA: 1-Hope Solo; 17-Lori Chalupny, 15-Kate Markgraf, 2-Heather Mitts, 3-Christie Rampone-Capt.; 7-Shannon Boxx, 11-Carli Lloyd, 9-Heather O’Reilly, 5-Lindsay Tarpley; 16-Angela Hucles, 8-Amy Rodriguez ... JPN: 1-Miho Fukumoto; 2-Yukari Kinga, 3-Hiromi Ikeda, 4-Azusa Iwashimizu, 7-Kozue Ando; 14-Kyoko Yano, 8-Aya Miyama, 10-Homare Sawa, 15-Mizuho Sakaguchi, 11-Shinobu Ohno, 17-Yuki Nagasato; retrieved 2012-8-29. This was a rematch of teams which played for the 2011 FIFA Women's World Cup. The match was played at the Wembley Stadium in London on August 9, 2012. The American team won the match 2-1.Parker, Graham. "Olympic women's soccer 2012 – USA 2-1 Japan - as it happened," The Guardian (UK).
